questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the setContentView() method in Android?
questions.options_json: {"A": "To set the layout for a new activity", "B": "To set the theme for an existing activity", "C": "To inflate a layout from XML", "D": "To create a new fragment"}
questions.explanation: The setContentView() method is used to inflate a layout from XML and set it as the content view of an Activity. This allows developers to define their UI in XML files.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the setContentView() method in Android?
questions.options_json: {"A": "To set the layout for the activity", "B": "To set the theme for the activity", "C": "To inflate a view from an XML file", "D": "To set the font style for the activity"}
questions.explanation: The setContentView() method is used to set the layout for the activity. This allows you to define the user interface of your app.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the 'apply' and 'merge' methods in Android's SharedPreferences?
questions.options_json: {"A": "To apply changes to the preferences immediately, without requiring a restart.", "B": "To merge new preferences with existing ones, overwriting any duplicate keys.", "C": "To save data locally on the device, such as user settings or app data.", "D": "To load default values for preferences if they are not set."}
questions.explanation: The 'apply' method applies changes to the preferences immediately, without requiring a restart. This is useful when you want to ensure that your app's settings take effect right away.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the 'onSaveInstanceState' method in Android?
questions.options_json: {"A": "To save the state of a fragment when it is detached from its activity", "B": "To save the state of an activity's UI components when it is paused or stopped", "C": "To save the state of a service when it is destroyed", "D": "To save the state of a broadcast receiver when it is unregistered"}
questions.explanation: The 'onSaveInstanceState' method is used to save the state of an activity's UI components, such as the current selection in a list view or the text in an edit text field. This allows the activity to restore its previous state when it is resumed.
